title: Lavender Tallow Balm: I Tried Beef Fat on My Face So You Don't Have To Be Weirded Out
body:
Okay so. I bought beef fat for my face. I know how that sounds. It was a Tuesday night, maybe Wednesday, and I was scrolling because my hands looked like old paper bags. Winter does that. The whole situation was very… beige. Dry. Cracking by my thumbs. I’d tried the fancy stuff in the blue jar, the one that costs like a decent lunch for two, and it did nothing. Just sat there. Felt greasy. So I’m looking at this Etsy shop, right, and I see “Whipped Tallow Balm.” Lavender. Made in France. My first thought was, obviously, “You want me to put what on my skin?” Tallow. Like, from a cow. For cooking. I pictured a candle. It sounded like something my great-grandma would have had in a tin, next to the lye soap. But the reviews were all these normal people saying it fixed their eczema or their kid’s rash or their own desert-face, and I was desperate. And curious. So I clicked buy. Figured if it was a disaster, at least it’d be a funny story.

It showed up a while later. The jar was smaller than I thought. Cute, though. Simple. I opened it sitting at my kitchen counter, the overhead light was too bright, and I poked it. Cold. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. Like cold butter that’s been whipped with a mixer for a long time. Thick but soft. I smelled it. Lavender? Kind of. But not like a candle or a cheap soap. More like… the actual plant. If you crushed a lavender bud between your fingers, that green, herby, almost sharp smell first, then the floral part. It was strong. Not perfume-strong, just… present. I was skeptical. I mean, beef fat? Seriously? But my knuckles were splitting. So I took a tiny bit, rubbed it between my palms. Cold at first. Then it just… melted. Went from this firm balm to almost nothing. I put it on the back of one hand. Waited. It didn’t feel greasy. It felt like my skin had just drunk it. Huh.

## Why Putting Beef Tallow on Your Skin Isn't Actually Crazy

So I had to look this up because I couldn't just be smearing dinner on my face without some reason. Here’s the thing. Our skin makes oil, right? Sebum. It’s a mix of fats. Tallow, especially from grass-fed cows, is apparently really similar to that mix. Like, structurally. So your skin recognizes it. It doesn’t just sit on top like a silicone coat from a lot of modern moisturizers—it gets absorbed. Actually gets in there. It’s an occlusive, meaning it locks moisture in, but it’s also nourishing because it’s packed with vitamins A, D, E, K. All that good stuff that’s already in our skin. This isn’t new science either. It’s old. Ancient, even. People have been using animal fats on their skin forever. Lanolin from sheep. Bear grease. Tallow. My grandma probably had a tin of something similar in her cupboard, now that I think about it. She had that “waste not, want not” mentality. Using the whole animal. It makes a grim kind of sense when you stop thinking of it as a “beauty product” and more as… food for your skin. Simple. No weird unpronounceable polymers. Just fat, whipped with some lavender oil and whatever else. Which reminds me, the ingredients list was short. Like, I could read it. Grass-fed beef tallow, lavender essential oil, maybe some vitamin E oil. That’s it. No water, so no need for preservatives. The simplicity of it got me. In a world of 30-step routines with serums in neon bottles, this was a jar of whipped fat. It was almost punk rock.

Anyway, back to the point. The science-y bit, casually explained: our skin barrier is made of lipids. Tallow is a lipid. Similar composition. It helps repair the barrier instead of just covering up the problem. It’s like giving your skin the building blocks it’s already trying to use. That’s why it’s supposed to be good for rough hands, fine lines, sensitive skin—it’s fixing the foundation. I’m not a chemist. This is just what I gathered from reading forums and some studies that popped up. It made enough sense to me to keep going.

## What Happened When I Actually Used The Stuff

I started with my hands. Desperate times. That first night, I globbed it on before bed. The lavender smell was strong in my dark room. Not like a sleep spray, but… earthy. Grounding. I fell asleep pretty fast, actually. Could’ve been placebo. Could’ve been the fact I was tired from work. But I woke up and my hands didn’t feel like sandpaper. They felt normal. Not “oh my god transformed” normal, just… not painful. The cracks were still there but less angry. So I kept doing it. Every night. After a week, the cracks on my thumbs were gone. Just… healed. My cuticles looked less like shredded wheat. I got brave and tried it on my face. I have combo skin, gets oily in the T-zone but flaky on the cheeks in winter. I was terrified it would clog my pores. I used a tiny, tiny amount, warmed it up in my hands, and patted it on my cheeks and forehead. It absorbed. Didn’t leave me shiny. My face just felt… calm. Not moisturized in a “I can feel the product” way. More like it just felt like my own skin, but better. Hydrated. Not tight.

Here’s a tangent—my sink was dripping while I was doing this. A slow, annoying *plink… plink… plink*. Drove me nuts. I had to get up and jiggle the handle. See? Distracted. Where was I. Right, the face. I didn’t break out. That was the big shock. If anything, my skin got less reactive. The red patches on my cheeks from the wind chilled out. I started using it as a night cream. The lavender thing became a ritual. Smell the jar, scoop a bit, the whole process took 30 seconds. It’s not a luxurious “spa experience.” It’s functional. It works.

## My Skin a Few Weeks In & The Weird Part

So it’s been like, a month maybe? I’m on my second jar now. I got one for my mom too, she has super dry skin and she called me last week saying her elbows haven’t been this smooth since she was a kid. High praise. My own skin just feels… resilient. Like I can go outside in the cold and my face doesn’t instantly scream. My hands look like human hands again, not a mechanic’s. The weird part, the part I didn’t expect, is that I don’t really think about my skin anymore. It’s not a problem to solve. It’s just there, doing its thing, comfortable. I spent so much money over the years on creams that promised miracles in glossy packaging. This stuff comes in a plain jar and it just… fixes the issue. No fanfare. It’s deeply unsexy. And I love that about it.

I got mine from this little Etsy shop that makes it in small batches. The owner was nice, answered my weird question about the sourcing (grass-fed beef tallow, from French farms, which matters for the nutrient profile apparently). It feels good supporting that instead of some mega-corp.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, I think so. For me it was. The logic checks out—it’s similar to our skin’s own oils, so it absorbs and helps repair the barrier instead of just sitting on top. It’s packed with vitamins. Sounds wild, but it works.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
It didn’t for me, and I was sure it would. Because it’s so similar to sebum, my skin seemed to know what to do with it. It sinks in. It’s not pore-clogging like mineral oil or some heavy butters can be. If you’re super acne-prone, maybe patch test. But for most people, no.

**What does the lavender tallow balm smell like?**
Real lavender. Not fake. It’s herby and green first, then floral. Strong when you open the jar, but it fades pretty quick once it’s on your skin. It’s calming. Makes it feel more like a nighttime thing.

So yeah. That’s my tallow story. I put beef fat on my face and I’m not sorry. My skin’s happy, I’m happy. If your skin’s being difficult this winter, or just in general, it might be worth a shot. It’s just one of those simple, old-school things that actually works. I’m probably gonna order another one soon.
